title: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content: This may be a post more for K:M, but I've seen a few comments here that indicate modding Keen4-6 is much more difficult than Keen1-3.  This would explain why there are far more mods for the early Keens, but having never tried modding myself, I was just wondering what people are finding the most difficult hurdle to get past when trying to make a Keen4 mod?

title: Re: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content:
Not having modded either myself, I can only give you a rough impression:

1. More graphics to edit.
2. Levels are more complex.
3. TED is a pain to set up and not compatible with many machines.

Anything else that makes K4-6 modding harder than K1-3 modding?[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]
[url=http://www.last.fm/user/grafix5000/][img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img][/url]

title: Re: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content:
I haven't done much in modding, but for what I have started on keen jailbreak (a mod in progress) I would say the hardest part is TED5, which is a right pain to use. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dead.gif[/img]

It generally uses more of everything really (than keen1-3)- disk space, sprites, etc. the only thing I can think of that it doesn't have more of is editing programs.

[img]http://i16.photobucket.com/albums/b33/freeyorp101/sig2.png[/img]

[hr]

The yorp shalt inherit the mars

title: Re: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content:
I have started a Keen 4 mod (made a storyline to fit into Keen 4's 'objectives' and such, and drawn a tileset and some sprites). The thing that put a stop to my modding was TED5 - I followed all the the instructions, but no matter what I edit/create, I always get a 'Map too tall' error...

So I would agree that, for the average modder, Keen 4-6 mods are more difficult to make than Keen 1-3 mods.--------------
[url=http://spikenexus.toxicsheep.com/pccw/][img]http://spikenexus.toxicsheep.com/pccw/imgs/links/pccwsml.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content:
That's interesting, I thought it would've been lack of tools (especially ones to edit the graphics) rather than the map editor.

Oh well, that certainly gives me an area to focus on with my game editor.

title: Re: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content:
Yeah, TED5 doesn't work at all for many, it's problematic.
And yeah, there's a way more enemies and stuff to replace, it takes a long time to draw the graphics. As well, the system is a bit different, one needs to set some strange coordinates.. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-confused.gif[/img]

Anyways, you're making a Keen 4 level editor? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-surprise.gif[/img] Eat your veggies!

title: Re: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content:
"Anyways, you're making a Keen 4 level editor? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-surprise.gif[/img] "

Yeah, this is part of the generic game editor I've been working on for ages now. I've finally got to the point where the architecture is complete enough to begin the real programming. The idea is that you'll only have to write code to read/write a specific file format (such as a Keen4 map, an IMF file, a Duke3D GRP file, or whatever) and the editing system will take care of the user interface. That way you only have to write a "2D map editor" once, and it'll work with everything from Xargon to Wolf3D.

title: Re: Are Keen4 mods difficult?
content:
What about [url=http://tilestudio.sourceforge.net/]Tile Studio[/url]? You only have to specify the file format. I haven't tried it, but it looks promising.

Unfortunately the Keen map format got lost with the many other posts during the attack against ezboard. Have someone saved it?[hr]The human brain is not user-friendly...

title: Tile Studio
content: Tile Studio looks cool.  But would it work for Keen Mods?

title: Re: Tile Studio
content:
Read z-1's post closer:
[quote]Quote:[hr]z-1 You only have to specify the file format.[hr][/quote]
Basically, Tile Studio won't work with Keen out of the box - it'll need someone to define the Keen map file format before it can load Keen levels.[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]
[url=http://www.last.fm/user/grafix5000/][img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img][/url]

And yeah, sounds like a promising stuff Malvineous.Eat your veggies!

Tile Studio looks promising - unfortunately it appears to be Windows only, so I guess I'll just go back to what I was doing before [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]

title: Re: Tile Studio
content:
At least it's open-source, though it was written in Delphi. Maybe it can be compiled with Kylix too.

Many of us could use it with windows, and it cannot be so hard to specify the map file format. There may be other programs like this out there, isn't there one for linux?

I understand if you want to create your own editor though. It feels nice to accomplish such thing.[hr]The human brain is not user-friendly...

title: Re: Tile Studio
content: Unfortunately no, there's nothing much out there for Linux - plus I enjoy programming so I don't mind writing my own.  That and the fact that I've figured out many file formats over the years and written quite a few extractors and convertors, so I'd like to put all that work together into the one program - a nice challenge [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: Tile Studio
content:
What are you using to make the editor?

Sounds good. I'll happily look at any alternative to TED5, as it takes a lot of time to make even one map with that, and some quite weird controls there to.

Good luck. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

content:
"What are you using to make the editor?"

C++. I'll probably have to get a lot of input from everyone here when it comes time to develop the map editor interface, as I'd like it to be as easy to use as possible, and my idea of "easy to use" is probably quite different to everyone else's!

title: well...
content:
The simplest way I can describe Keen4 vs. Keen1 modding is to point out the difference between the two Keen sprites.

Keen1: 32 sprites, actions are run, jump, pogo, shoot, die, freeze.

Keen4: 85 sprites, actions are stand, run, jump, pogo, shoot, mid-air shoot, die, pole-climb, pole-shoot, ledge-grab and climb, enter door, idle stance, swimming, and dying when swimming.

That all by itself is nearly three times the amount of work required--keeping in mind that the sprite size for Keen4 is about 50% larger than Keen1.

Now compare the tilesets:

Keen1: A little over 600 tiles to account for the entirety of the mod: Must include background, foreground, solids and points, keys and doors, hazards and animated objects.

Keen4: About eight times that. Approximately 3,000 mid- and fore-ground tiles (each with individual masking) plastered over 1,200 background-only tiles.

And finally, the enemy complexity:

Keen1: Seven enemies. Yorps, Gargs, Vorticons, Butlerbots, Tankbots, 3 different ice cannons, and the Chain (used more in mods than Keen1 itself)

Keen4: At least twice that. Poison Slugs, Sprites, Skypests, Licks, Berkeloids, Arachnuts, Bounders, Council Members, Clouds, Bluebirds, Gnosticene Ancients (candy stealers), the Dopefish, Schoolfish, Mines, and Mad Mushrooms (as well as any others I forgot).

Again, remember than Keen4's sprites are at about 50% larger than Keen1's.

It's going to take a long time to find a comprehensive way to put together all those little pieces without it seeming completely arbitrary.
